Chapter Five THE NIGHT OF THE ZENITH I: “I trust her illness is nothing serious,” Riveda put in, casually but with a piercing glance from beneath heavy-lidded eyes, “I have often thought that these night vigils in the damp air do no good to anyone.”

Noon paled and retreated, and Domaris, raising herself as if by instinct, saw Micon walking slowly along the shore. She got to her feet, her hair tumbling loose about her waist, her dress billowing in the wind, and began to run toward him on impatient feet. Hearing the quick, uneven steps, he stopped.

It seemed a long time, although it was barely past noon, when Cetris sent for the Priestess. To Domaris’s complete astonishment, Deoris came into the room with her. It was the first time since the ceremony that Domaris had seen her sister robed as a Priestess of Caratra, and for a moment she hardly recognized the little white face beneath the blue veil. It seemed to her that Deoris’s face was the most welcome thing she had ever seen in her life.

Deoris stroked the little girl’s shoulder gently, and her own face grew stern. Her last shred of doubt vanished. Riveda heard her crying? In a sealed sound-chamber? That I’ll believe taken the sun shines at midnight!

“Find Ragamon the Elder and Cadamiri, and bid them summon the Guardians to meet here at high noon. Then seek the Arch-priest Talkannon, and say to him quietly that we have at last found evidence. No more—he will understand.”
